i18n-intro: Opt out of PRISM, the NSA’s global data surveillance program. Stop reporting your online activities to the American government with these free alternatives to proprietary software.
i18n-linuxmint-desc: Comfortable and easy to use GNU/Linux distribution.
i18n-liberte-desc: Live CD/USB designed as a communication aid in hostile environments.
i18n-tails-desc: Live CD/USB aimed at preserving your privacy and anonymity.
i18n-disconnect-desc: Stop third-party sites from tracking you.
i18n-httpseverywhere-desc: Encrypts your communications from thousands of websites.
i18n-noscript-desc: Only enable JavaScript, Java, and Flash for sites you trust.
i18n-seeksproject-desc: Open decentralized platform for collaborative search.
i18n-namecoin-desc: Distributed DNS based on Bitcoin technology.
i18n-bitcoin-desc: P2P digital currency with no central authority.
i18n-cryptocoins-desc: List of alternative encrypted digital currencies.
i18n-tormail-desc: Tor Mail is a free anonymous email service provider.
i18n-clawsmail-desc: Lightweight email application with GPG support.
i18n-evolution-desc: Free email and calendar application with GPG support.
i18n-kmail-desc: KDE email client with GPG support.
i18n-gitannex-desc: Synchronize folders on your computers and drives.
i18n-seafile-desc: Self-hosted file sync and collaboration for teams.
i18n-sparkleshare-desc: Self-hosted version control and file sync.
i18n-tahoelafs-desc: Free and open cloud storage system.
i18n-friendica-desc: Privacy respecting, distributed, federated social network.
i18n-otr-desc: Install and enable this plugin in Pidgin for encrypted chat.
i18n-adium-desc: Free, multiprotocol chat client for OS X.
i18n-fdroid-desc: Free and open source app store for Android.
i18n-gibberbot-desc: Private, secure OTR messaging for Android.
i18n-fsf-definition-title: *This website uses the Free Software Foundation’s definition of free software.
i18n-fsf-quote: “Free software” means software that respects users’ freedom and community. Roughly, the users have the freedom to run, copy, distribute, study, change and improve the software. With these freedoms, the users (both individually and collectively) control the program and what it does for them.
i18n-eff-title: Take action against PRISM at the Electronic Frontier Foundation Action Center.
i18n-eff-quote-2: Recent reports by the Guardian and the Washington Post confirm secret spying programs on phone records and Internet activity. It's time for a full accounting of America's secret spying programsâ€”and an end to unconstitutional surveillance.
i18n-operating-system-note: Apple, Google, and Microsoft are a part of PRISM. Their proprietary operating systems cannot be trusted to safeguard your personal information from the NSA.This leaves us with two free alternatives: GNU/Linux and BSD. GNU/Linux has a much larger community to help you with the transition. It's recommended that you begin your explorations by looking for a GNU/Linux distribution that suits your needs.Canonical’s Ubuntu is not recommended by PRISM Break because it contains Amazon ads and data leaks by default.Note: PRISM Break recommends the no-codecs edition of Linux Mint, as the other editions are encumbered with software patents. More info.
i18n-android-note: CyanogenMod licensing: “CyanogenMod does still include various hardware-specific code, which is also slowly being open-sourced anyway.” —WikipediaF-Droid is a free alternative to the Google Play app store.
i18n-ios-note: iOS is insecure, and unfortunately there aren't a lot of free encryption apps available for iOS either. It's also impossible to verify if an iOS app was compiled from the original source.
i18n-web-browser-note: Use a combination of Tor Browser and another free browser to surf the web. Try to use Tor for everything. Browsing the web may be a bit slower, but it's far more secure.Note that using Tor Browser to log into PayPal or a banking website may trip the website’s fraud protection software.Users of Tor Browser should also be aware that logging into HTTP (instead of HTTPS) websites may result in your credentials being captured by a malicious exit node.Note: Mozilla Firefox is technically not completely free software, as Mozilla recommends non-free add-ons on their website.
i18n-web-browser-addons-note: Safeguard your privacy and stop websites from tracking you by installing Adblock Edge, Disconnect, HTTPS Everywhere, and NoScript in your browser.Cryptocat and Mailvelope are browser addons for IM and email encryption, respectively. At this time, it may be more secure to use external software for more proven encryption. Why not Adblock Plus? Adblock Plus shows “acceptable ads” by default, and uses more memory than Adblock Edge. Why not Ghostery? Ghostery is a proprietary plugin. Use Disconnect instead.
i18n-web-search-note: Startpage is proprietary, hosted in the USA/Netherlands, and provides you with anonymized Google search results (including images).DuckDuckGo is partly proprietary, hosted in the USA, and provides you with anonymized Bing search results.Pick your poison.
i18n-email-services-note: Bitmessage is a promising alternative to email, but it’s is not ready for daily usage. Use at your own risk.Riseup is hosted in the USA. It’s also beginning to offer VPN, chat, and etherpad services.Why not Hushmail? See “compromises to email privacy”.The only way to have full control over your email is to run your own mail server. This is not for everyone though, as it requires considerable time investment and technical knowledge.While not complete yet, the FreedomBox project is aiming at creating a turnkey solution for encrypted communications.
i18n-email-clients-note: Here is a guide to encrypting your email with Thunderbird, GNU Privacy Guard (GPG), and Enigmail.Note: Mozilla Thunderbird is technically not completely free software, as Mozilla recommends non-free add-ons on their website.
i18n-email-encryption-note: “Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) is a data encryption and decryption computer program that provides cryptographic privacy and authentication for data communication. PGP is often used for signing, encrypting and decrypting texts, e-mails, files, directories and whole disk partitions to increase the security of e-mail communications.”— Wikipedia
i18n-social-networking-note: identi.ca is a popular Twitter-like social networking hub for the free and open source software community. The site is converting to the pump.io software platform sometime this week.
i18n-instant-messaging-note: Cryptocat in the Web browser add-ons section may be of interest as well.
i18n-video-voip-note: Jitsi is a drop-in, encrypted replacement for almost all the tasks Skype is used for.Mumble an open source voice chat client in the style of Ventrilo and TeamSpeak.WebRTC is an upcoming, promising browser to browser communications API.
i18n-online-transactions-note: The Bitcoin blockchain is a decentralized, public ledger of all transactions in the Bitcoin network.“It may be the TCP/IP of money.” —Paul Buchheit
i18n-media-publishing-note: Self-hosted is important. Hosting your blog on WordPress.com is no better for your data security than Blogger or Tumblr.
i18n-cloud-storage-note: Why not MEGA? While MEGA is free as in beer, the software is proprietary.Why not SpiderOak? SpiderOak is proprietary software.Why not Tarsnap? Tarsnap is partially proprietary and hosts your data on Amazon Web Services.
i18n-web-analytics-note: Piwik analytics powers this site. It's set up to anonymize the last octet (255.255.255.???) of visitor IPs. Check out the live data here: prism-break.org/analytics.
i18n-dns-provider-note: Google Public DNS permanently logs your ISP and location information for analysis. Your IP address is also stored for 24 hours.OpenNIC does not log anything.
i18n-darknet-note: “A darknet is an anonymizing network where connections are made only between trusted peers.Darknets are distinct from other distributed P2P networks as sharing is anonymous, and therefore users can communicate with little fear of governmental or corporate interference.“—Wikipedia
i18n-disclaimer: Disclaimer: Using the recommended projects on this site will not guarantee that 100% of your communications will be shielded against surveillance states. Please do your own research before trusting these softwares with sensitive information.
